name: BP Induction (Classroom)
description: This course is intended to inform personnel about the work that BP does on the North Slope of Alaska. You will discuss the hazards that may be encountered in Prudhoe Bay and in the oil & gas industry in Alaska, emergency information, camps and facilities details, road and weather conditions, safe driving rules and much more. This course is required for all personnel working on BP sites and/or projects in Alaska.

name: Fire Watch  (ARSC)
description:
This Fire Watch training applies to all persons who test or monitor the atmosphere, including confined space entrants, and those requiring knowledge of the following principles: 


•    Define hot work

•    Describe hot work precautions

•    Identify when a fire watch is required

•    Identify the elements for a fire

•    Define the five classes of fire

•    Recognize the symbols fire extinguisher classes

•    Describe precautions for preventing fires from spreading

•    Identify responsibilities and tasks of a fire watch

•    Describe the steps for inspection of fire extinguishers before use

•    List the maximum travel distances to fire extinguishers

•    Define the Permit Authorizing Individual responsibilities

•    Identify when hot work permits are invalid and not permitted

•    Describe supervisor and employee responsibilities 

•    Describe use of fire extinguisher

•    Describe use of hose line equipment

name: PPE Module (NSTC)
description:
Goal:

To prepare participants to recognize typical job hazards where personal protective equipment (PPE) may be required to minimize the risk of personal injury.


Objectives:

Participants will be able to:

Recognize hazards in the workplace.

Explain the three hazard control measures and give examples of each.

Describe the PPE required in relation to the task being performed and what part(s) of the body could be injured.

List the limitations of PPE.


NSTC - 06

Revised 1-2022

"

name: NSTC: Respiratory Protection: 3: SCBA

name: Infection Prevention and Control
description: This course covers basic hygiene and how to prevent and control the spread of infection in the workplace. It explains infection prevention and control in the workplace, standard precautions of infection control, common infections and modes of transmission, how to identify and report situations that pose a risk for infection and how to control the spread of infection. It encourages everyone to take responsibility for their own hygiene and to help prevent and control the spread of infection in the workplace.

name: H2S/FeS Module (NSTC)
description:
Goal:

To ensure participants can recognize the hazardous characteristics of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and iron sulfide (FeS) and correctly apply the standards and procedures to safely perform work in areas where H2S and FeS are found.

 Objectives:

Participants will be able to:

Identify the characteristics of H2S.

List the hazards of H2S.

Describe the effects of various H2S concentration levels on humans.

Recognize the need for monitors and alarms which identify the specific levels of H2S concentrations.

Describe the proper notification procedures for an H2S emergency.

Describe the appropriate rescue and emergency procedures for a person exposed to high levels of H2S.


NSTC-21

Revised 1-2022

name: HAZCOM Module (NSTC)
description:
Goal:

To ensure participants can recognize the health and physical hazards of chemicals used in the workplace and take steps to control those hazards in accordance with 2012 GHS update of OSHA 29 CFR 1910.1200.

Objectives:


Participants will be able to:

Explain the purpose of the 2012 GHS Hazard Communication Standard Update.

Explain the components of a hazard communication program.

Use hazard classifications
subscribe_method:
and other resources to identify and control the physical and health hazards of chemicals used in the workplace.


NSTC 05

Revised 1-2022

name: Alaska Safety Handbook Module (NSTC)
description:
The goal of this course is to provide participants with practice in using the 2022 Alaska Safety Handbook as a reference for the safety procedures that guide daily North Slope work habits and behaviors.


Registration includes a hard copy of the 2022 Alaska Safety Handbook. Please be sure  you have added your mailing address to your profile and it is up-to-date.

name: NSTC Policies and Procedures
description:
Introduction

The mission of the NSTC is to develop, maintain, and manage high quality, health, safety, and environmental training curriculum and instruction for the employee and contractor work force on the North Slope and at other industrial sites in Alaska.

The NSTC Policies & Procedures Manual will be followed to ensure consistent and quality delivery and reporting of the NSTC training to participating organizations.



Scope

The NSTC Policies & Procedures Manual applies to all NSTC training processes involving Alaska’s oil and gas producers, transportation companies, refineries, and their contractor companies. The major operators funding the North Slope Training Cooperative are BP Exploration (Alaska), Inc.; ConocoPhillips Alaska, Inc.; ENI Operating Co. Inc.; ExxonMobil Alaska Production, Inc.; Hilcorp Alaska, LLC; and Oil Search (Alaska) LLC.

name: NSTC Unescorted
description:
The 8-hour Unescorted Course is required for all employees prior to arrival on the North Slope. It consists

of 6 modules (the 6-Pack). Each module makes use of lecture, discussion, individual and

 small group exercises, and quizzes to involve employees in their own learning. Upon completion of the

course, employees receive an NSTC card, which allows them to travel unescorted within and between the

operating fields to which they are assigned.


 Module I: Introduction, Camps and Safety Orientation is an introduction to the unique working

conditions at Alaska’s North Slope oil and gas facilities and the importance of working safely.


 Module II: Alaska Safety Handbooks is an overview of the ALASKA SAFETY HANDBOOKS

which provide the basic safety standards and requirements for daily tasks and projects in the operating

areas on the North Slope.


 Module III: Personal Protective Equipment provides an overview of typical job hazards where

personal protective equipment may be required to minimize the risk of injury.


 Module IV: HAZCOM reviews the components of a hazard communication program, the types of

hazardous chemicals, and the resources available for identifying and controlling those hazards.


 Module V: HAZWOPER, First Responder Awareness focuses on the proper response to releases or

potential releases of hazardous substances with special emphasis on the DOT Emergency Response

Guidebook and DOT Pipeline Awareness.


 Module VI: Environmental Excellence emphasizes personal responsibility for following environmental

rules and regulations relating to air, land, water, wildlife, spills, and waste management as detailed in

the NORTH SLOPE ENVIRONMENTAL FIELD HANDBOOK.

name: AK-CESCL Refresher
description:
The AK-CESCL Refresher is a summary of the two-day initial AK-CESCL class. This course thoroughly examines erosion and sediment pollution control concepts and design procedures as they apply to construction projects. The Refresher Course is a training and certification program to comply with the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation Construction General Permit. The Refresher Course will stress risk management, review proper best management practices, and provide guidance.


Prerequisites: An attendee must have an active AK-CESCL number and have completed the two-day (16-hour) or the one-day (8-hour) refresher course within the past 3 years.

name: AK-CESCL 2-day Certification
description: AK-CESCL training is a two-day course that includes erosion and sedimentation processes, the regulatory requirements, Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plans, Best Management Practices, inspection, record-keeping, and cold climate challenges.  To become certified, an individual must attend the entire course and pass a written exam. The AK-CESCL certification is valid for three years.

name: NSTC Instructor Application
description:
To become an Instructor for the North Slope Training Cooperative (NSTC), individuals are required to submit an online Instructor application with a non-refundable $75 application fee. Applicants must include a current resume, have a relevant HSE background, knowledge and ability to address technical safety questions or concerns posed by class participants, presentation or instruction experience, and a minimum of six-months experience working on Alaska's North Slope.


Individuals must submit a complete application packet and application fee, and be currently employed by an Operator, Contractor company or Labor Union that adheres to the Alaska Safety Handbooks (ASH), or by a licensed NSTC Third-Party Provider. Applicants who meet the required experience will be accepted as an NSTC Instructor Candidate. 


Once accepted as an NSTC Instructor candidate, individuals will then attend a full-day Instructor Orientation at the Alaska Safety Alliance office in Anchorage. NSTC Instructor Candidates will be invoiced for the Instructor Orientation; $325 for current ASA members, $425 for non-members, which covers all training, materials, and the Instructor's evaluation.


All NSTC curriculum and Instructor training materials, and one set of the Alaska Safety Handbook (ASH) and Environmental Field Handbook (EFH) will be provided at the Orientation. The Instructor Candidate will need to provide an Endorser signature from their immediate supervisor or manager, which serves as a company endorsement of the Instructor’s qualifications, and an acknowledgment of participation as an NSTC Instructor.


Please direct any NSTC questions to the Alaska Safety Alliance (907)770-5250

name: NSC - First Aid/CPR/AED Full Course
description: Alaska Safety Alliance offers *National Safety Council First Aid, CPR & AED courses. This 6-hour course provides training for rendering aid to adults utilizing National Safety Council guidelines, materials and practices. This course has a renewal period of 2 years for all components. Please note: You must be physically able to perform all requirements of this training.  For further information please contact the Alaska Safety Alliance at (907) 770-5250.

name: ARSC Fire Watch Test
description:
This Fire Watch training applies to all persons who test or monitor the atmosphere, including confined space entrants, and those requiring knowledge of the following principles: 

•    Define hot work

•    Describe hot work precautions

•    Identify when a fire watch is required

•    Identify the elements for a fire

•    Define the five classes of fire

•    Recognize the symbols fire extinguisher classes

•    Describe precautions for preventing fires from spreading

•    Identify responsibilities and tasks of a fire watch

•    Describe the steps for inspection of fire extinguishers before use

•    List the maximum travel distances to fire extinguishers

•    Define the Permit Authorizing Individual responsibilities

•    Identify when hot work permits are invalid and not permitted

•    Describe supervisor and employee responsibilities 

•    Describe use of fire extinguisher

•    Describe use of hose line equipment



"

name: NSTC HAZCOM Module
description:
Goal:

To ensure participants can recognize the health and physical hazards of chemicals used in the workplace and take steps to control those hazards in accordance with 2012 GHS update of OSHA 29 CFR 1910.1200.

Objectives:


Participants will be able to:

Explain the purpose of the 2012 GHS Hazard Communication Standard Update.

Explain the components of a hazard communication program.

Use hazard classifications
subscribe_method:
and other resources to identify and control the physical and health hazards of chemicals used in the workplace.


NSTC 05

Revised 1-2022

name: Welcome to Alpine
description: This course is required for all individuals staying at ConocoPhillips' Alpine Camp. It contains general information vital to a safe stay at Alpine.

name: AK-CESCL Refresher
description:
The AK-CESCL Refresher is a summary of the two-day initial AK-CESCL class. This course thoroughly examines erosion and sediment pollution control concepts and design procedures as they apply to construction projects. The Refresher Course is a training and certification program to comply with the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation Construction General Permit. The Refresher Course will stress risk management, review proper best management practices, and provide guidance.


Prerequisites: An attendee must have an active AK-CESCL number and have completed the two-day (16-hour) or the one-day (8-hour) refresher course within the past 3 years.

The goal of this course is to provide participants with practice in using the 2022 Alaska Safety Handbook as a reference for the safety procedures that guide daily North Slope work habits and behaviors.


Registration includes a hard copy of the 2022 Alaska Safety Handbook. Please be sure  you have added your mailing address to your profile and it is up-to-date.

name: english
AK-CESCL 2-day Certification
description: AK-CESCL training is a two-day course that includes erosion and sedimentation processes, the regulatory requirements, Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plans, Best Management Practices, inspection, record-keeping, and cold climate challenges.  To become certified, an individual must attend the entire course and pass a written exam. The AK-CESCL certification is valid for three years.
